• M1 is awarded for the correct calculation of a week’s total milk consumption, which would be 7 × (3/8) litres. In this answer, the student incorrectly uses 3 litres per day and multiplies by 7, so M1 is not awarded.

b.answer:
Angle BCD = 20°

Working:
• Angle ABC = 125° and angle ADC = 125°.
• Since PQRS is a rectangle, angle BAD is 90°.
• The sum of angles ABC, BAD, ADC, and BCD around A and D is 360°.
  So:
  125 + 90 + 125 + BCD = 360
  BCD = 360 − (125 + 90 + 125) = 20°
b.rationale:
• B1 is earned for identifying angle BAD = 90° (as PQRS is a rectangle).
• M1 is earned for using the correct angle sum 360 − (125 + 90 + 125).
• A1 is earned for the correct final answer of 20°.
The step for PAB = 45° is not shown, so the candidate does not earn that extra B1, giving 3 marks instead of 4 here.

b.rationale: • B1 for identifying angle PAB = 45° (from AP = PB in rectangle geometry). • B1 for recognizing angle BAD = 90° (right angle in rectangle). • M1 for correctly summing angles to 360° and subtracting 125°, 90°, and 125°: 360 − (125 + 90 + 125) = 20. • This leads to the correct final answer angle BCD = 20°, scoring 4 marks in total (2 AO2.1a and 2 AO2.4a).

b.answer: The triangle’s area is ½ × 6 × 8 = 24 cm². The area of the parallelogram is three times 24, which is 72. As its base is 18 cm, 72 = 18 × h. So h = 72 ÷ 18 = 4 cm.

• B1 for the correct final answer of 4 cm.

a.answer: I worked out 10% of 50 000 by calculating 50 000 × 1.1, giving 55 000. Hence, the value of goods sold in February is £55 000.
a.rationale: According to the mark scheme, 2 marks (M1 and A1) are awarded for subtracting 10% of 50 000 (i.e. 5 000) or doing 50 000 × 0.9, leading to 45 000. Here, the method is incorrect (using 1.1 instead of 0.9) and the final answer (55 000) is not 45 000, so neither the method mark nor the accuracy mark can be given, resulting in 0/2.

b.answer: Each month, the sales value increased by 10%. So from 50 000 in January they became 55 000 in February, then 60 500 in March, then 66 550 in April, and next 73 205 in May. Since 73 205 is more than 35 000, the shop stays open beyond May.
b.rationale: The mark scheme awards up to 3 marks for correctly multiplying by 0.9 each month (or equivalent 10% reduction) and proving that May’s sales are under 35 000. This answer uses a 10% increase instead of a 10% decrease, so it does not demonstrate the correct repeated reduction or the correct threshold comparison. Hence no marks can be awarded, 0/3.

a.answer: I chose the primes 2 and 3. Their sum is 5, and that is odd.

Therefore, no mark is awarded for part (b).

b.answer:
I will label the eight sections: 6, 6, 4, 4, 3, 3, 3, 3.

Working:
- There are three different numbers in total (6, 4, and 3).
- This is an example arrangement, ensuring the spinner has eight equal sections with three numbers.
b.rationale: Part (b) in the mark scheme awards 3 marks (B1 for each of the three properties: ‘three different numbers’, ‘more even numbers than odd’, and ‘6 appears most’). This answer only achieves ‘three different numbers’ (B1) but does not satisfy ‘6 appears most’ nor ‘more even numbers than odd’ since 6 and 4 add to four even sections while 3 occupies four odd sections, and 3 is more frequent than 6. Therefore, it achieves 1 of the 3 available marks.

a.i.rationale: According to the markscheme, the correct number here is 5 because the spinner shows 5 on three of its six sections, giving a probability of 3/6 = 1/2. This matches ‘It is evens that the spinner will land on number _______.’ The answer of 5 directly meets the A1 requirement for part (i), gaining 1 mark.

a.ii.rationale: From the markscheme, there is exactly 1 section labeled ‘1’ out of the 6 total sections, so the probability is 1/6. This gains the single A1 mark for part (ii).

a.iii.rationale: The markscheme shows the answer can be any number not appearing on the spinner (i.e., any number other than 1, 3, or 5). Saying 7 makes it impossible for the spinner to land on that number. This satisfies the condition for 1 A1 mark in part (iii).

b.answer:
I will show one arrangement of eight sections: 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 3, 3. 

Working:
• There are eight total sections.
• I chose the numbers 6 and 3. 6 appears 6 times, and 3 appears 2 times.
• So the spinner has more chances of landing on an even number (6) than on an odd number (3), since 6 out of 8 is for the even number 6 and only 2 out of 8 is for the odd number 3.
• 6 clearly appears the most often.
b.rationale: Three marks are available: (1) for having three different numbers, (2) for making sure 6 appears the most, (3) for having more even numbers than odd. This answer only shows two distinct numbers (6 and 3). Hence it does not fulfill the ‘three different numbers’ requirement, losing 1 mark. It still satisfies that 6 appears most frequently and that there are more even than odd sections, earning 2 marks.

a.i.rationale: According to the spinner shown (6 equal sections), the number 5 appears on 3 out of the 6 sections, so the probability is 3/6 = 1/2. The question states “It is evens that the spinner will land on number …”, meaning a probability of 1/2, so 5 is correct. This matches the mark scheme: 1 mark for identifying 5 as having a probability of 1/2.

a.ii.rationale: There is exactly one section showing the number 1 out of 6 sections, giving a probability of 1/6. This satisfies the requirement “There is a probability of 1/6 that the spinner will land on number …”. This aligns with the official mark scheme for 1 mark.

a.iii.rationale: The spinner shows only the numbers 1, 3, and 5 in its six equal sections, so it is impossible for the spinner to land on any other number. Stating 2 (or any number not in {1, 3, 5}) receives the 1 mark according to the official mark scheme.

b.answer:
One possible arrangement around the 8-section spinner is: 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 3, 3, 5.
Working:
• There are 8 sections in total.
• Three distinct numbers: 6, 3, and 5.
• 6 appears 5 times, which is more than either 3 or 5.
• There are 5 evens (all 6s) and 3 odds (two 3s and one 5). So the probability of landing on an even number (6) is 5/8, which is greater than 3/8 (the probability of an odd). 6 is indeed the most frequent number.
Thus all conditions are satisfied.
b.rationale: The mark scheme for part (b) awards 3 marks for: (1) having exactly three different numbers, (2) ensuring 6 appears more often than each other number, and (3) ensuring the spinner has more even sections than odd. The suggested layout with five 6s, two 3s, and one 5 meets these criteria and achieves full marks.

0.answer: Average speed = 5 ÷ x hours. Converting to metres and seconds does not change this expression, so the final answer is 5/x m/s.
0.rationale:
In order to achieve any marks for Question 18, a candidate must show correct conversions from kilometres to metres, hours to seconds, and then use a correct division to arrive at x/18. The mark scheme specifically awards:

• B1 for converting x kilometres to 1000x metres (which was not done here)
• B1 for converting 5 hours to 5×60²=18000 seconds (which was not done here)
• B1 for forming a correct expression involving x, 1000, 18000, leading to x/18 (which was not done here)
• B1 (or equivalent accuracy marks) for a correct final answer of x/18 (which was not given)

This response provides an incorrect expression of 5/x for average speed in m/s. It omits the necessary distance and time conversions and does not simplify to the required x/18. Hence, no marks are awarded.

1.answer:
Distance = x km = 1000x m
Time = 5 × 60 = 300 seconds
Average speed = 1000x ÷ 300 = 10x/3 m/s
1.rationale: In the mark scheme, a B1 mark is awarded for correctly stating that x kilometres is 1000x metres. The time has been incorrectly converted to 300 seconds instead of 18000 seconds (5 hours × 3600), so the subsequent method for average speed is wrong and does not lead to x/18 m/s. Therefore, only 1 mark (B1) can be awarded.

2.answer: Average speed = distance ÷ time = x ÷ 5 km/h. To convert km/h into m/s, multiply by 1000 to get metres and divide by 3600 to get seconds. So x/5 km/h = (x/5) × (1000/3600) m/s = x/18 m/s.
2.rationale:
For question 18, two of the four available marks might be awarded as follows:
• One mark can be given for writing the speed as x/5 km/h and partially demonstrating a correct unit conversion (for instance, acknowledging that 1 km/h = 1000/3600 m/s).  
• One mark can be given for obtaining the final expression x/18 m/s.  
The other two marks from the markscheme (which include explicit mention of x km = 1000x m and 5 hours = 60² × 5 seconds or more in-depth working) are not fully addressed here, so this answer is likely to achieve 2 marks in total.

3.answer:
Average speed = distance ÷ time = x ÷ 5 km/h.

To convert from km/h to m/s, note that 1 km = 1000 m and 1 hour = 3600 s. So:

x/5 km/h = (x/5) × (1000 / 3600) = x/18 m/s.

Hence the average speed is x/18 m/s.
3.rationale:
By the mark scheme:
• B1 is earned for expressing speed as distance ÷ time = x/5 km/h.
• B1 is earned for converting x kilometres into metres and using the correct idea that 1 hour is 3600 seconds (which gives the x/5 × 1000/3600 step).
• B1 is earned for reaching the final expression x/18 m/s.
They have not separately shown 5 hours = 60² × 5 seconds, so one mark is not awarded, giving 3 marks in total.

4.answer:
Average speed = Distance / Time
= (x kilometres) / (5 hours)
First convert x kilometres to metres: x km = 1000x metres.
Then convert 5 hours to seconds: 5 × 60 × 60 = 18000 seconds.
So average speed in m/s = (1000x) / 18000 = x/18 m/s.
4.rationale:
• B1 for correctly converting x km to 1000x metres (from the markscheme: x km = 1000x m).
• B1 for correctly converting 5 hours to 18000 seconds (from the markscheme: 5 hours = 60² × 5).
• B1 for using the correct formula for average speed in m/s, i.e. (distance in metres)/(time in seconds).
• B1 for simplifying to get x/18 m/s as the final expression. This matches the required form and earns full marks according to the markscheme.

a.answer: Triangles ABC and EDC each have a right angle at B and D respectively. Also, they share the angle at C in the sense that the angles there match in both triangles. This means they have the same angles overall and so are similar by angle–angle–angle.

b.answer: We know DE = 3.5. The ratio BC : CD = 3 : 1, so BC = 3 × CD. By similarity, the scale factor between DE and AB should be the same as between CD and BC. So we do 3.5 × 3 = 10.5. Therefore, AB = 7.

a.answer: Triangles ABC and EDC each have a right angle at B and D respectively. Also, angle ACB equals angle ECD because they are vertically opposite. Since they share two equal angles in total, the triangles must be similar.

b.answer: In triangles ABC and EDC, AB corresponds to ED and BC corresponds to CD. Given BC : CD = 3 : 1, we have BC/CD = 3. Since AB/ED = BC/CD, then AB = ED × 3 = 3.5 × 3 = 10.5 m.
b.rationale: • The correct answer is 10.5 m. • 1 method mark is given for calculating 3.5 × 3. • The second accuracy mark is awarded for the correct final result of 10.5.

a.answer:
To show that triangles ABC and EDC are similar:

First, angle B is a right angle and angle D is also a right angle. Next, angles ACB and ECD are vertically opposite, so these angles are equal. Because both triangles have two pairs of equal angles, they must share all three angles in common. Hence, triangles ABC and EDC are similar.
a.rationale:
• One mark is awarded for identifying that angles at B and D are right angles.
• One mark is awarded for recognizing that angles ACB and ECD are vertically opposite and therefore equal.
• One mark is awarded for stating that, with these equal angles, the two triangles share all three angles and are therefore similar.

b.answer: Using the fact that triangles ABC and EDC are similar, the ratio of corresponding sides is the same. We know BC : CD = 3 : 1 and DE is 3.5 m. Since AB corresponds to ED, AB : ED = BC : CD. So AB : 3.5 = 3 : 1, giving AB = 3 × 3.5 = 10.5 m.
b.rationale:
• One mark is awarded for the correct process of multiplying 3.5 by 3 (or an equivalent use of the ratio 3:1).
• One mark is awarded for the correct final answer of 10.5.

0.rationale: To earn marks from the mark scheme, the candidate needs to: (1) correctly combine 25% (1/4) and 1/2 of the rent, (2) set 1/4 of the rent equal to 450, (3) find the total by multiplying 450 by 4, and (4) arrive at £1800. This response does not show 1/4 + 1/2 = 3/4 (no M1), does not equate 1/4 of the rent to 450 (no M1), does not multiply 450×4 (no M1), and the final answer is not £1800 (no A1). Therefore it earns 0 marks in total.

1.answer: Charlie pays 25% and Mo pays 50%. That makes 75% in total. The remaining 25% of the rent is £450, so I think the total rent must be £900.
1.rationale: According to the mark scheme, one possible route to a single mark (M1) is correctly identifying that Charlie and Mo together pay 75% of the rent, and that Andrzej’s share is 25%. Although this step is correct (so awarding 1 method mark), the final multiplication to find the total is done incorrectly, so the remaining marks are not earned.

2.answer:
Charlie and Mo pay a total of 75% of the rent, so the remaining 25% is Andrzej’s share which is £450. This suggests that 1% = 450 ÷ 25, but I multiplied 450 by 3 to find the 75% share:
75% share = 450 × 3 = £1350 (I made a calculation error and took this as 450 × 3 = 1200 in my final step), so the total would then be 1200 + 450 = £1650.

Answer: £1650
2.rationale:
I used the idea that Mo pays ½ and Charlie pays ¼, giving ¾ in total, so Andrzej must pay the remaining ¼. I identified that ¼ of the rent is £450, which aligns with the second method mark (M1 for ¼ (of rent) = 450). However, I incorrectly completed the total calculation. According to the mark scheme:
• M1 can be awarded for adding fractions ¼ + ½ = ¾.
• M1 can be awarded for correctly spotting that ¼ of the rent is £450.
I did not accurately multiply 450 × 4, so I lose the next method mark that leads to the correct total of £1800, and I do not get the final accuracy mark. Therefore, I only achieve a total of 2 marks.

3.answer: Let the total rent be R. Charlie pays 25% of the rent. That means 25% of R equals £450. Therefore, R = 450 × 4 = £1800. So they pay £1800 in total.
3.rationale: rationale: The candidate has not shown the partial step ¼ + ½ = ¾, so the first M1 from the markscheme (for adding fractions) is not awarded (M0). They are awarded M1 for identifying that ¼ of the rent is £450, M1 for multiplying 450 by 4 to find the total rent, and a final accuracy mark A1 for giving £1800 as the total. Hence total marks: 3.

4.answer: Charlie pays 25% (which is 1/4) of the rent. Since Andrzej pays £450, that must be 1/4 of the total rent. Therefore, the total rent is 450 × 4 = 1800. Finally, 1800 is the amount they pay altogether.
4.rationale:
• M1: Adding Charlie’s fraction and Mo’s fraction: 1/4 + 1/2 = 3/4 (soi)
• M1: Recognising that 1/4 of the rent corresponds to £450
• M1: Multiplying 450 by 4 to get the total rent
• A1: Final correct total = £1800

Hence, the total rent is £1800, achieving all 4 marks according to the mark scheme.

Answer to Question 4:

Antonio works from 4:00 pm to 10:30 pm on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. That is 10:30 – 4:00 = 6.5 hours each day.

He is paid £10 per hour on weekdays, so total from weekdays = 19.5 × £10 = £195.

On Sunday, he works for 4 hours and is paid 50% extra.
This means Sunday rate = £10 + 50% of £10 = £10 + £5 = £15 per hour.
So Sunday pay = 4 × £15 = £60.

Total pay for the week = £195 + £60 = £255.

0.answer:
Kieran: 24
Jermaine: 24
Chris: 24

Working:
I noticed they have a total of 72 goals. I just divided 72 by 3 to get 24 goals each for Kieran, Jermaine and Chris.

Because Jermaine has 5 more than Kieran and Kieran has 8 more than Chris, I assumed equal values were fine.
0.rationale:
Detailed reasoning:

• M1 is not awarded because no correct equation is formed or attempted (e.g. x – 8 + x + x + 5 = 72, or equivalent), so there is no valid algebraic method shown.
• The second M1 mark is not earned as there is no follow-up from an initial correct equation or any valid rearrangement (3x – 3 = 72, 3x = 75, x = 25, etc.).
• There is no correct substitution into expressions such as x – 8 and x + 5, so no additional M1 is awarded.
• The final numbers (24, 24, 24) do not meet the conditions (Kieran should have 8 more than Chris, and Jermaine should have 5 more than Kieran), therefore no A marks or B marks can be awarded.
• No special case (SC) marks apply because the correct answer (Kieran=25, Jermaine=30, Chris=17) is not given at any stage.

Hence, the total marks awarded are 0.

1.answer:
Let K = Kieran’s goals.
Jermaine = K + 5
Chris = K − 8

K + (K + 5) + (K − 8) = 72
3K − 3 = 72
3K = 72
K = 24

So, Kieran = 24, Jermaine = 29, Chris = 16.
1.rationale: I formed the correct equation K + (K+5) + (K−8) = 72, which earns 1 M (method) mark according to the scheme (M1). However, my rearrangement to 3K = 72 is incorrect and leads to the wrong values for Kieran, Jermaine, and Chris, so the accuracy marks and further method marks are not awarded. Therefore the total is 1 mark.

2.rationale: The student has provided the correct final answers (25, 30, and 17) with insufficient or no working shown. Referring to the mark scheme, if the correct triple of answers is given but there is no adequate supporting method (leading otherwise to 0 or 1 marks), then SC2 is awarded for 2 total marks.

3.answer:
Let K be x, so Chris = x − 8 and Jermaine = x + 5. Then their total is (x − 8) + x + (x + 5) = 72.
This simplifies to 3x − 3 = 72, so 3x = 75 and x = 25.
Therefore, Kieran scored 25 goals, Jermaine scored 30 goals, and Chris scored 16 goals.
3.rationale: First, 1 mark is awarded for forming the correct equation (x−8 + x + x+5 = 72). Next, 1 mark for correctly simplifying to 3x−3=72 and solving for x=25. Then 1 further mark is awarded for some correct substitution into x−8 and x+5 (even though the final tally for Chris is not correct, the partial working up to Jermaine is correct). The final answer to Chris is incorrect, so the full accuracy marks are not earned, leaving a total of 3 marks.

4.answer:
Let K be Kieran’s goals. Then Chris’s goals are K − 8, and Jermaine’s goals are K + 5. Altogether:
K + (K − 8) + (K + 5) = 72
So 3K − 3 = 72, which gives K = 25.
Therefore, Chris scored 17, Jermaine scored 30, and Kieran scored 25.
4.rationale:
To see how this work would be marked according to the scheme:

• M1 is awarded for forming the correct expression K + (K − 8) + (K + 5) = 72 (the basis of 3K − 3 = 72).
• M1FT is given for rearranging correctly to 3K − 3 = 72.
• M1FT for finding K = 25 (implied by 3K − 3 = 72), though the step 3K = 75 is not explicitly shown.
• M1 for substituting K = 25 back to find Chris = 17 and Jermaine = 30.

All three final numbers are correct, so the candidate meets much of the method requirement. However, not all steps are shown in full detail (e.g. the step from 3K − 3 = 72 to K = 25 is not explained). Therefore, an examiner might award 4 marks in total instead of the full 5.

5.answer:
Let Kieran be x.
Then Chris = x − 8 (because Kieran has 8 more goals than Chris), and Jermaine = x + 5 (because Jermaine has 5 more goals than Kieran).

So their total is:
 x + (x − 8) + (x + 5) = 72
 3x − 3 = 72
 3x = 75
 x = 25

Hence:
 Kieran = 25
 Chris = 25 − 8 = 17
 Jermaine = 25 + 5 = 30
5.rationale: M1 is awarded for correctly setting up x + (x−8) + (x+5) = 72. M1FT is awarded for forming 3x − 3 = 72. M1FT is also earned by solving 3x − 3 = 72 leading to x = 25. A further M1 is awarded for substituting x = 25 back to find Chris = 17 and Jermaine = 30. Finally, the completely correct solution and final answers (25, 30, 17) with correct working earn the 5th mark in total.

3.answer: I can make 231 by doing (6 + 1) × 11 × 3. First, I add 6 and 1 to get 7. Then I multiply 7 by 11 to get 77. Finally, I multiply 77 by 3 to get 231. So my answer is 231.
3.rationale: I used all four numbers (6, 1, 11, and 3) once, only using +, ×, and brackets without powers or combining digits, to produce 231. According to the mark scheme guidance, a number greater than 200 with complete correct working can receive M3. Even though 264 is the actual maximum, 231 is still above 200 and the working is correct, so it gains partial credit. Hence, this response would receive 3 marks in total.

4.rationale: In this solution, each of the four given numbers 11, 1, 3, and 6 is used once. The working is correct and clearly communicated: (3 + 1) gives 4, multiplied by 6 gives 24, and multiplying by 11 gives 264 as the final answer. According to the mark scheme, the correct final answer of 264 with complete clear working earns all 4 marks: 1 method mark for setting up a valid calculation involving all four numbers in a correct way, plus the remaining 3 marks for a fully correct, clearly communicated final answer and method.

5.answer:
16(a) I looked at different ways to combine 11, 1, 3, and 6 using brackets and the four operations. I ended up finding that if I add 3 and 1, then multiply by 6, and finally multiply by 11, I get 264.

• First, 3 + 1 = 4
• Then, 4 × 6 = 24
• Finally, 24 × 11 = 264

16(b) So the biggest number I made is 264, by calculating (3 + 1) × 6 × 11.
5.rationale:
16(a) (Method Marks)
- M1: A number over 200 is attempted or shown.
- M1: Attempts to use the four numbers together meaningfully. In my work, I have shown (3 + 1) then multiplied by 6 and 11.

16(b) (Accuracy and Explanation)
- A1: Correct final answer of 264 (or a correct calculation making over 200) not from incorrect working. I get that for providing 264.
- A1: Clear steps: (3 + 1) = 4, 4 × 6 = 24, 24 × 11 = 264, which matches the marking scheme for correct working.

I did not fully show why 264 is definitely the maximum possible, so one mark is withheld, leading to a total of 5 marks overall.

6.answer: To get the biggest number, first add 3 and 1 to make 4. Then multiply 4 by 6 to get 24, and finally multiply 24 by 11 to get 264. So (3 + 1) × 6 × 11 = 264.
6.rationale:
Mark breakdown:
• M1: Evidence of a valid attempt to combine the numbers (e.g. adding some of them together or multiplying). 
• M2: Correctly using at least one operation in a way that reaches or exceeds 200 (such as 24 × 11 or something similar). 
• M3: A fully correct method using all four numbers (3, 1, 6, 11) in a clear chain of steps with multiplication and/or addition. 
• A1: Reaching the final correct result of 264.
• An additional 2 marks (to make 6 in total) are awarded here for the clear, correctly communicated working and for explaining how no bigger total can be achieved using these operations without powers or concatenation.

Explanation:
We first add 3 and 1 to make 4 (showing clear combination of two numbers), then multiply 4 by 6 to make 24, and then multiply 24 by 11 to reach the maximum possible value of 264. This uses each number exactly once and employs allowed operations. The result 264 is correct and is the highest that can be achieved under the given constraints.

a.answer: To check if 21 is in the sequence 3n + 5, solve 3n + 5 = 21. Subtracting 5 from both sides gives 3n = 16, and 16 ÷ 3 is not an integer. Therefore there is no integer n that makes the term 21, so 21 is not a term of the sequence.
a.rationale: • M1 is earned by correctly applying the form 3n + 5 = 21 and showing 3n = 16. • A1 is earned by concluding that 16 ÷ 3 is not an integer, so 21 cannot appear as a term. This aligns with the mark scheme requirement to demonstrate that 21 is not of the form 3n + 5 for an integer n.

b.i.rationale: According to the mark scheme, 1 mark is awarded for any valid rule and correct next two terms following that rule. Here, the rule is to increase the difference by 1 each time, yielding the correct next two terms of 7 and 11.

b.ii.answer: Rule 2: Double the previous term. Since 1, 2, and 4 double to 2, 4, and 8 respectively, the next term after 4 is 8, and the term after 8 is 16. The next two terms are 8 and 16.

a.answer: I think the first error occurs in Step 1, because I see that x² + 4x + x + 4 should simplify to x² + 5x + 3 instead of x² + 5x + 4.
a.rationale: The mark scheme awards 2 marks (B1 for identifying Step 2 as the first error, and B1 for explaining that −3x − 2x = −5x rather than −x). This answer incorrectly identifies Step 1 instead of Step 2 and provides an incorrect reason, so no marks are awarded here.

b.answer:
Starting with (x + 1)(x + 4) = (x – 2)(x – 3):

Left side: x² + x + 4
Right side: x² − 2x − 3

So the equation is x² + x + 4 = x² − 2x − 3
⇒ x + 4 = −2x − 3
⇒ 3x = −7
⇒ x = −7/3
b.rationale: According to the mark scheme, a correct solution must expand correctly to x² + 5x + 4 and x² − 5x + 6, leading to x = 1/5. This answer uses incorrect expansions (x² + x + 4 on the left, x² − 2x − 3 on the right) and yields x = −7/3. Since neither the method nor the final answer is correct, it gains 0 out of 2 marks.

a.answer: Amin made his first error in Step 2. He had −3x − 2x on the right-hand side, but he combined these incorrectly as −x instead of −5x. This made the rest of his solution go wrong thereafter.

b.answer: Expanding (x + 1)(x + 4) gives x² + 5x + 4. Expanding (x – 2)(x – 3) incorrectly as x² − 3x + 6, I then set x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 3x + 6, which leads to 5x + 4 = −3x + 6. Solving 8x = 2 gives x = 1/4. (Incorrect.)

a.answer: The first mistake is made in step 2. The term −3x − 2x should have been −5x, not −x.

b.answer:
Correct expansion: (x+1)(x+4) = x² + 5x + 4 and (x−2)(x−3) = x² − 5x + 6
So x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6
10x + 4 = 6
10x = 2
x = 1/4

a.answer: The first error is made in Step 2. Amin combined −3x and −2x incorrectly, writing −3x − 2x = −x instead of −5x.

b.answer: Starting with (x + 1)(x + 4) = (x − 2)(x − 3), expand both sides: x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6. Subtract x² from both sides: 5x + 4 = −5x + 6. Add 5x to both sides: 10x + 4 = 6. Subtract 4 from both sides: 10x = 2. Divide by 10: x = 1/5.
b.rationale: • M1 (method mark) for correctly expanding and rearranging the equation: x² + 5x + 4 = x² − 5x + 6, leading to 10x = 2. • A1 (accuracy mark) for the correct final solution x = 1/5, in line with the mark scheme.

0.answer: I will use 10 litres of red paint only, which costs £80 for 10 litres. Then I sell one 10-litre tin of pink paint for £60. So I think the profit is £60 − £80 = −£20. Therefore, Peter loses £20 on each tin he sells.

1.answer: In 10 litres of paint, I divide it in the ratio 2 : 3 to get 4 litres of red paint and 6 litres of white paint.
1.rationale: By correctly splitting 10 litres into the ratio of red to white (2 : 3) to get 4 litres of red and 6 litres of white, the student earns one method mark (M1). No further steps or correct final profit calculation have been provided, so only 1 mark is awarded.

2.rationale: For question 19, this answer simply states the correct final profit of £25 but does not provide enough working to earn the full method or accuracy marks. 3.answer:
He mixes red and white in the ratio 2:3 for every 10 litres of pink paint.
This means 2/5 of 10 = 4 litres of red paint and 3/5 of 10 = 6 litres of white paint.

Red paint costs £80 for 10 litres, so that is £8 per litre.
White paint costs £5 for 10 litres, so that is £0.50 per litre.

The cost of 4 litres of red paint is 4 × £8 = £32.
The cost of 6 litres of white paint is 6 × £0.50 = £3.

So the total cost for 10 litres of pink paint is £32 + £3 = £35.

[No further working shown]
3.rationale:
• First, the ratio step 2:3 was used correctly to find that, out of 10 litres, 4 litres are red and 6 litres are white. According to the markscheme, this approach is worth M1.
• Next, identifying red paint as £80 for 10 litres (so £8 per litre) and white paint as £5 for 10 litres (so £0.50 per litre) and applying these to 4 litres and 6 litres respectively corresponds to another M1.
• Calculating 4 × 8 + 6 × 0.50 to get 32 + 3 = 35 shows the correct method to determine the total cost of one 10-litre can, which earns a further M1.
• Because the final step of subtracting this cost from the selling price (£60) is not completed, the M1 for profit calculation and the final A1 mark for an accurate final answer are not awarded. Therefore, this response achieves a total of 3 marks.

4.answer: I use the ratio 2 : 3 for red : white in a 10-litre tin, so 4 litres are red and 6 litres are white. The cost for the 4 litres of red paint is £32 and the cost for the 6 litres of white paint is £3, making a total cost of £35. He sells the paint for £60 per 10-litre tin, so his profit is £60 − £35 = £25.
4.rationale: • M1 is earned for using the ratio to find that there are 4 litres red and 6 litres white in each 10-litre tin. • M1 is earned for calculating the cost of these amounts (e.g. 4 litres of red, 6 litres of white). • M1 is earned for summing these costs to get £35. • M1 is earned for subtracting the cost from the selling price (60 − 35). This yields the correct answer of 25 and demonstrates enough method to score four marks. One method step is not fully shown (such as explicitly calculating £8 per litre of red or £0.50 per litre of white), so one mark is lost.

5.answer: To mix 10 litres of pink paint in a 2 : 3 ratio, I use 4 litres of red paint and 6 litres of white paint. Red paint costs £80 for 10 litres, so this is £8 per litre. White paint costs £5 for 10 litres, so this is £0.50 per litre. The cost of the red paint for one 10-litre tin is 4 × £8 = £32. The cost of the white paint for one 10-litre tin is 6 × £0.50 = £3. So the total cost of making one 10-litre tin of pink paint is £32 + £3 = £35. Peter sells each 10-litre tin for £60, so his profit per tin is £60 − £35 = £25!
5.rationale:
• First M1 is awarded for correctly splitting the 10 litres of pink paint into 4 litres red and 6 litres white, in line with the ratio 2 : 3 (mark scheme: “M1 for 10 × (2/5) = 4 litres red, or for 10 × (3/5) = 6 litres white”).
• Second M1 is given for calculating the cost per litre of each type of paint correctly: £80 ÷ 10 litres = £8 per litre for red, and £5 ÷ 10 litres = £0.50 per litre for white (mark scheme: “M1 for red costs £8 per litre or white costs £0.50 per litre”).
• Third M1 is for working out the total cost of one 10-litre tin by multiplying the volumes by the respective cost per litre (4 × £8 + 6 × £0.50) to get £35 (mark scheme: “M1 for cost of one can is (their 4 × their 8) + (their 6 × their 0.5)”).
• Fourth M1 is awarded for subtracting the cost price from the selling price (60 − 35 = 25) (mark scheme: “M1 for (60 − their 35)”).
• The final answer of £25 profit, shown with supporting calculation, earns the accuracy mark (mark scheme: “Answer: 25 with correct working; 5 marks if not from wrong working”).

1.answer: I know that the probability the train to work is on time is 0.3 and the probability home is on time is 0.6. So 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18. Therefore, the probability that at least one train is late is 0.18.
1.rationale: In the mark scheme, a single correct product (like 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18) earns M1. However, the final answer is not correct because it does not complete the method to find the probability that at least one train is late. Thus, only 1 mark is awarded.

2.answer:
Probability(train to work on time) = 1 - 0.7 = 0.3
Probability(train home on time) = 0.6
So, Probability(both on time) = 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18
Therefore, Probability(at least one late) = 1 - 0.18 = 0.72
2.rationale: For question 21, the candidate correctly identifies 0.3 and 0.6 as the probabilities of each train being on time, and calculates their product 0.18 (M1). They then use the method 1 - (probability both on time) for the probability of at least one being late, which earns a second method mark (M1). However, the final calculation for 1 - 0.18 is incorrectly given as 0.72 (should be 0.82), so no accuracy marks are awarded. This yields a total of 2 marks.

3.answer: I will calculate the probability that neither train is late and subtract this from 1. The probability that the train to work is on time is 1 − 0.7 = 0.3, and the probability that the train home is on time is 1 − 0.4 = 0.6. So the probability both trains are on time is 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18. Therefore, the probability that at least one train is late is 1 − 0.18 = 0.81.
3.rationale: For question 21, the student correctly identified that the probability of at least one train being late is 1 minus the probability that both are on time, and used the correct figures of 0.3 and 0.6. This correct method would normally earn 3 method marks (M3 according to the mark scheme: 1 − 0.18 or the equivalent sum of products). However, there is a small arithmetic slip, since 1 − 0.18 should be 0.82 rather than 0.81, causing the final accuracy mark (A1) to be lost. Hence the total is 3 marks.

4.answer:
Probability that both trains are not late: 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18.
Therefore, the probability that at least one train is late = 1 − 0.18 = 0.82.
4.rationale:
Question 21:
• M1 is awarded for correctly identifying and employing at least one correct product, for example using 0.3 (the probability the train to work is on time) or 0.6 (the probability the train home is on time), or by writing one correct product such as 0.3 × 0.6.
• M2 is awarded for two correct products or partial methods, such as calculating 0.3 × 0.6 = 0.18 and recognizing that the complement 1 − 0.18 can be used.
• M3 is awarded for a complete correct method, like systematically calculating 1 − (0.3 × 0.6) or summing up all the relevant probabilities correctly (0.7 × 0.4 + 0.7 × 0.6 + 0.3 × 0.4), ensuring the correct approach for “at least one is late.”
• A1 is awarded for the final accurate answer of 0.82.
Thus, the total of 4 marks is achieved.

c.answer: I think Sam’s assumption is fine because the team can work full days nonstop, so her answer is probably correct.

a.answer: First, 3 people put 600 letters in 2 hours, which means in 1 hour they put 300 letters. So 1 person puts 100 letters in 1 hour. With 4 people, each hour they put 400 letters, so in 2 hours they put 800 letters.
a.rationale: • M1 is earned by correctly finding the rate per person (e.g. 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour). • A1 is then earned by correctly scaling up for 4 people over 2 hours, giving 800. This matches the markscheme awarding 2 marks in total.

b.answer: One person can put 100 letters in 1 hour, so 5 people take 2 hours for 1000 letters. For 4 people, I worked out 4 x 100 letters per hour = 400 letters per hour. 1000 ÷ 400 gave 2.5 hours, but I rounded that to 3 hours. Therefore, it takes about 1 hour longer than with five people.
b.rationale: • M1 is awarded for stating a correct per-person rate (100 letters/hour). • M1 is awarded for calculating the time for 5 people (2 hours). The final conversion for 4 people is incorrect (2.5 hours to 3 hours), so the final difference stated (1 hour) does not match the official correct 30 minutes difference. This partial correctness achieves 2 method marks and loses accuracy marks.

a.answer: First, in two hours three people can put 600 letters into envelopes. This means one person does 200 letters in two hours. So four people in two hours can put 800 letters in envelopes.
a.rationale: I used the unitary method to find how many letters one person does in two hours (200) and then multiplied by 4 for four people, giving 800. According to the mark scheme, this secures M1 for the correct unitary approach and A1 for the correct final answer of 800.

b.answer: One person can do 100 letters in 1 hour, so five people put 1000 letters in 2 hours. I then assumed that four people would put 1000 letters in about 2 hours 15 minutes, meaning it would take 15 minutes more for four people than for five people.
b.rationale: I used the idea that one person does 100 letters per hour, but my times for four or five people contain an error. The mark scheme awards an M1 for the initial rate of 100 letters per hour, but further method and accuracy marks are lost because the times for four and five people are not correctly worked out, meaning I only gain partial credit (1 mark).

c.answer: Sam is not being reasonable because she assumes people can keep working at the same rate for an entire day without a break. This makes her total too high since in reality they wouldn’t work continuously for 24 hours.

a.answer: First, 3 people put 600 letters into envelopes in 2 hours. So they do 600 letters in a total of 3 × 2 = 6 person-hours. One person’s rate is 600 ÷ 6 = 100 letters per hour. In 2 hours, 1 person puts 200 letters into envelopes. Four people, each putting 200 letters in 2 hours, means 4 × 200 = 800 letters in 2 hours.
a.rationale: By the markscheme M1 is earned for correct unitary work (e.g. 1 person does 200 letters in 2 hours). A1 is awarded for the correct final answer of 800 letters. This achieves 2 marks in total for part (a).

b.answer: Since 1 person can put 100 letters in 1 hour, 1 person can do 1000 letters in 10 hours. Therefore, 5 people take 10 ÷ 5 = 2 hours to put 1000 letters in envelopes. 4 people take 10 ÷ 4 = 2.5 hours to do the same job. So 4 people take 0.5 hours (30 minutes) longer than 5 people.
b.rationale: M1 for finding 1 person’s rate (100 letters/hour). M1 for working out the time for 5 people (1000 letters in 2 hours). M1 for working out time for 4 people (2.5 hours). Final difference of 30 minutes gains the accuracy mark. This collects 4 marks as per the scheme.

c.answer: Sam is correct that 600 × 12 = 7200 letters in a day, so her calculation should be fine. It seems perfectly reasonable if people keep working at the same rate all day with no breaks.

a.answer: First, find how many letters one person can put in envelopes in two hours. Three people can put 600 letters in 2 hours, so one person can put 200 letters in 2 hours. Therefore, four people can put 4 × 200 = 800 letters in two hours.
a.rationale: • M1 for unitary method (3 people → 600 letters in 2 hours implies 1 person → 200 letters). • A1 for final answer of 800 letters.

b.answer:
First, find how many letters one person can put in envelopes in one hour. Three people put 600 letters in 2 hours, which is 300 letters per hour for 3 people, so 1 person puts 100 letters per hour.

Five people putting 1000 letters: 1000 ÷ (5 × 100) = 2 hours.
Four people putting 1000 letters: 1000 ÷ (4 × 100) = 2.5 hours.

Difference = 2.5 − 2 = 0.5 hours, which is 30 minutes.
Therefore, it takes 30 minutes longer for four people than for five people.
b.rationale: • M1 for finding one person’s rate as 100 letters/hour. • M1 for calculating time for 5 people. • M1 for calculating time for 4 people. • A1 for the correct difference of 30 minutes.

c.answer: Sam assumes they work continuously at the same rate all day, which is not realistic. People cannot keep working at the same pace for 24 hours straight.
c.rationale: • B1 for identifying that the assumption of continuous work throughout the entire day is not reasonable. (Does not clearly state it leads to an overestimate, so only 1 mark.)

a.answer: First, three people take 2 hours to put 600 letters in envelopes. This means each person does 100 letters in 1 hour, or 200 letters in 2 hours. Four people would then do 4 × 200 = 800 letters in 2 hours.

• A1 is for the correct final answer of 800 letters

b.answer: One person does 100 letters in 1 hour. Therefore five people do 1000 letters in 2 hours. Four people will do 1000 letters in 2.5 hours. The difference in time is 2.5 − 2.0 = 0.5 hours, which is 30 minutes.
b.rationale:
• M1 for finding that 1 person does 100 letters in 1 hour
• M1 for calculating that 5 people put 1000 letters in 2 hours
• M1 for calculating that 4 people put 1000 letters in 2.5 hours
• A1 for the correct time difference of 30 minutes

c.answer: Sam assumed they could work at the same rate continuously for 24 hours with no breaks. This is not realistic. As a result, the total number of letters she calculated is an overestimate, because workers cannot keep up that pace all day.
c.rationale:
• B1 for explaining that the assumption of continuous work all day is not reasonable
• B1 for explaining that this assumption leads to an overestimate of how many letters can be done

a.answer:
I will calculate the amount after three years for each account by just adding the yearly percentages in a simple way.

Account A: 3% each year, so total interest after three years = 3% + 3% + 3% = 9%. 9% of £10,000 is £900, so the total would be £10,900.

Account B: 4% + 3% + 2% = 9% as well. 9% of £10,000 is £900, so the total would also be £10,900.

Therefore, Account B gives more by 50p because of small rounding differences I noticed when adding up the percentages.
a.rationale: The correct method (M marks) requires compounding interest separately for each year or using the product of multipliers. The candidate has merely added the percentages, so no M marks are awarded. No correct final comparison or difference (A marks) is present, therefore A0. There is no correct numeric result or partially correct final answer to award B marks. The candidate also does not receive SC marks for correct difference with no working, as the difference is not the correct 103p and the working is incorrect. Overall, 0 marks.

So Account B is better.

I am not completely sure about Account B’s total, but I think Account B might be bigger overall.

The correct difference and correct identification of the better account is made, so they gain SC3 marks according to the mark scheme for a correct final difference with insufficient working (instead of the full M2M2 approach).

a.answer:
Account A:

Amount after 3 years = 10000 × 1.03³ = 10000 × (1.03 × 1.03 × 1.03) = £10927.27

Account B:

• M2 is awarded for correctly calculating the value in Account B, 10000 × 1.04 × 1.03 × 1.02 = 10926.24 (or equivalent rounded). This satisfies the second method mark requirement.
• An accuracy mark is awarded for obtaining the correct difference of £1.03 and identifying Account A as better by 103p.
Hence this working and final answer together match the mark scheme for 5 marks in part (a).

2.answer: He would probably take more than 120 seconds to complete 800 m because it’s harder to maintain his short-distance sprint speed over a much longer distance, so he will slow down and it will take him longer than his simple scaling suggests.
2.rationale:
This answer correctly states that Darren will be slower over 800 m and that it would take more than 120 s. According to the mark scheme:
• B1 is awarded for identifying that his speed will be slower over 800 m.
• B1 is awarded for concluding that it will take more than 120 seconds.

However, it does not refer explicitly to the incorrect assumption that Darren can maintain the same sprint speed (100 m in 15 s) over a longer distance. Consequently, it achieves 2 out of the 3 available marks.

3.answer: He would take more than 120 seconds because he is assuming he can keep the same speed for 800 m that he has for 100 m. In reality, it is not possible to maintain that top speed for eight times the distance, so he will slow down over 800 m. Therefore, it will take him longer than 120 seconds.
3.rationale:
• B1: Darren assumes he can run 800 m at the same speed he runs 100 m (i.e., 100 ÷ 15 = 800 ÷ 120). This addresses the assumption.
• B1: Over a longer distance, he will likely tire and run at a slower speed, so he cannot maintain that initial pace.
• B1: Conclusion that he will take more than 120 seconds. These points match the mark scheme requirements.

a.answer: I think 0.38 × 0.26 might actually be 0.827 because if you add 0.38 and 0.26 you nearly get 0.64, and 0.827 is not far from that, so it seems fine.

a.answer: When you multiply two decimals that are each less than 1, the result must be less than either decimal. Here, 0.38 × 0.26 cannot equal 0.827 because 0.827 is bigger than both 0.38 and 0.26.
a.rationale: According to the mark scheme for part (a), awarding 1 mark (AO2.5a) requires a clear, sensible reason. The explanation correctly states that the product of two decimals less than 1 should be smaller than each of them, so 0.827 must be wrong. This satisfies the mark scheme point that the answer should be smaller than 0.38 or 0.26, so we grant 1 mark.

a.answer: When multiplying two decimals less than 1, the result must be smaller than either decimal. 0.38 × 0.26 must be less than 0.38, so 0.827 is incorrect.
